examples.en: I'm living alone and I forgot to set my clock back an hour when the winter time started.
examples.ja: 一人暮らしをしているので、冬時間が始まった時に、時計を一時間遅らせることを忘れてしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: If 暮らす is "to live" or "to live one's life," then to live one's life as 一人, means you are <vocabulary>living alone</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the vocab readings from 一人 and 暮らす, so you should be able to read this on your own. Just note that くらし changes to ぐらし due to rendaku.

examples.en: My brother is such a shameless liar. He told me he had no idea what happened, but he was the one who ate all my bacon.
examples.ja: あの俺の兄貴は恥知らずの嘘つきだ。何の事だかサッパリ分からないなんて言ってたくせに、俺のベーコンを平らげたのはアイツだったんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: 恥 is a "disgrace." If you 知らず then you don't know something. In this case, you don't know disgrace, and a person who doesn't know disgrace is a <vocabulary>shameless person</vocabulary>, because they don't care what disgraces them and what doesn't.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 恥 and 知る put together.

examples.en: Studying on the train is common for Japanese students who suffer from exam hell.
examples.ja: 試験地獄に苦しむ日本の学生にとっては、電車で勉強するのは当たり前のことです。

meaning_mnemonic: An "examination hell" is the nickname given to the exams you have to take in Japan all at once. That's why this is <vocabulary>exam hell</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that smooshes two previous vocabulary words together into a new one. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I got over my seasickness with this medicine.
examples.ja: この薬で船酔いを克服しました。

meaning_mnemonic: When you're <kanji>boat</kanji> <kanji>drunk</kanji> you have <vocabulary>sea sickness</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 船 goes to ふな (probably because you're sick and can't spell). The 酔い comes from 酔う.

examples.en: She made her boyfriend cook kimchi hotpot.
examples.ja: 彼女が彼氏にキムチ鍋を作らせた。

examples.en: Have you ever tried soy milk hotpot?
examples.ja: 豆乳鍋を食べてみたことはありますか？

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 鍋 means "<kanji>cooking pot</kanji>"? This is the suffix version of that, so it means ____<vocabulary>hotpot</vocabulary> or ____<vocabulary>stew</vocabulary>. 

Usually 〜鍋 will come after the name of the soup base or main ingredient, like 味噌鍋 (miso hotpot) or キムチ鍋 (kimchi stew).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We offer 5% off if you pay with cash.
examples.ja: 現金払いにしていただけるなら、5パーセント引きにさせていただきます。

examples.en: Kanji characters should be written with attention to the stop, brush-up, and brushing-off strokes.
examples.ja: 漢字は止め、跳ね、払いに注意して書きましょう。

examples.en: Did you know that paying insurance premiums annually is more economical than paying monthly?
examples.ja: 保険料は月払いよりも年払いの方がお得なの、知ってた？

meaning_mnemonic:
If 払う is "to pay" or "to brush off," then the noun version is <vocabulary>payment</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>brushing off</vocabulary>.

Usually 払い is tacked on the end of another word, like in カード払い (payment by credit card).

When it indicates a kind of brushing off or brushing away, it appears in words like 足払い (sweeping an opponent's legs in judo) or, more figuratively, せき払い (clearing one's throat).
reading_mnemonic:
The reading comes from 払う, so know that and it will pay forward your knowledge to this one.

Note that when 払い is added to the end of a compound, it becomes ばらい.

examples.en: I bought this oil painting for 1500 yen at a flea market.
examples.ja: この油絵はフリマで千五百円で買ったんですよ。

examples.en: My grandmother used to collect oil paintings.
examples.ja: 祖母は油絵を集めていた。

examples.en: What's the most famous brand of oil paints?
examples.ja: 油絵用の絵の具で有名なブランドは？

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>oil</kanji> <kanji>painting</kanji> is an <vocabulary>oil painting</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi for 油 (which you learned with the vocabulary) and the on'yomi for 絵 (which you learned with the kanji).

examples.en: During lunch the other day for some reason one of the students pulled a bottle of sweet vinegar out of her desk.
examples.ja: この間、給食の時に生徒が何故か机の中から甘酢の瓶を取り出したのよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Sweet</kanji> <kanji>vinegar</kanji> is <vocabulary>sweet vinegar</vocabulary>. Them Japanese love their sweet things.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 甘い plus 酢, combined together. It's the kun'yomi readings, but that's probably because we're combing two words into one. It also changes the す to ず so, remember that.

examples.en: Kids can take the most mundane, random things and get so excited.
examples.ja: 子どもっていうのは、どんなささいなことでも手当たり次第に盛り上がることができるのよね。

meaning_mnemonic: 盛り上げる is "to heap up" - this has a similar idea, except now this is more like an excitement or swelling. As excitement heaps up in you, you are going <vocabulary>to get excited</vocabulary>. Note how 上がる is in here. This means something is happening to you (or something else), but you're not doing the action. When you get all sorts of excitement building up in you, you aren't really doing it, it's just happening on its own in reaction to something else.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 盛り and 上がる. Let the excitement build as you realize you know the reading already.

examples.en: My computer is very slow because it’s running out of hard drive space.
examples.ja: 私のパソコンはハードディスクの容量が無くなってきているので、動作がすごく遅いです。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>slow</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>slow</vocabulary> (or, if you're slow, you're probably <vocabulary>late</vocabulary>, too).
reading_mnemonic: How <vocabulary>slow</vocabulary> are you? You are <reading>oh so</reading> slow (おそ).

examples.en: Although she was determined to become a stripper, she’s still shy about dancing naked in public.
examples.ja: ストリッパーになると自分で決断したにも関わらず、彼女はまだ人前で裸で踊ることを恥ずかしがっているんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: 恥ずかしい is "embarrassing." This is the verb version. What happens when someone is embarrassed? They become shy and bashful. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to be shy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be bashful</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 恥ずかしい.

examples.en: Why do my pants always start wearing out in the butt area first?
examples.ja: ズボンのお尻の部分がいつも最初に破れるんだけど、どうしてだろう。

meaning_mnemonic: If 破る is "to tear" or "to rip," then this is <vocabulary>to get torn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get broken</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get ripped</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 破る.

examples.en: Whenever I introduce myself, I quickly run out of things to say.
examples.ja: 自己紹介では、いつもすぐ言うことがなくなっちゃうんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: A one's self (自己) introduction (紹介) is a <vocabulary>self introduction</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It’s hard to choose which girl to introduce to you.
examples.ja: お前にどの娘を紹介するかを選ぶのは難しいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A 紹介 is an introduction. So the verb version is <vocabulary>to introduce</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Helps that I introduced introduction to you earlier.

examples.en: You need a referral letter from a doctor to make an appointment at this hospital.
examples.ja: この病院で予約をするには、お医者さんからの紹介状が要ります。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how a 年賀状 is a new year's card? This is another kind of card/letter, but this time it's for an introduction (紹介), making it a <vocabulary>letter of introduction</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know 紹介 as well.

examples.en: He asked the waitress three times if there was any soup in the restaurant and she answered no each time. She was bewildered.
examples.ja: あいつ、あのウェイトレスさんに三回もこのレストランに汁物はないのかって聞きやがったんだぜ。ウェイトレスさんその度にありませんって言ってさ、困惑してたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>soup</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is what you use to refer to <vocabulary>soups</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is both the kun'yomi readings combined to form one word. So, you'll want to make sure you know the word 汁.

examples.en: "We have to finish eating this miso soup by tomorrow." "Okay, let’s get it over with."
examples.ja: 「明日までに、この味噌汁を飲んでしまわなければならないよ。」「じゃあ、さっさと片付けちまおうぜ。」

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 味噌 is "miso," and that 汁 is "soup." So, combine them together and you have <vocabulary>Miso Soup</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 味噌 plus the vocab 汁 put together.

examples.en: My heart was pounding while I was hassled by a drunk last night.
examples.ja: 昨日の夜酔っ払いに絡まれた時、心臓がドキドキしました。

meaning_mnemonic: If you're so <kanji>drunk</kanji> that you'll be <kanji>pay</kanji>ing for it later, it's safe to say you're a <vocabulary>drunk person</vocabulary>. You're way past being tipsy at this point, and you're definitely going to pay for it… with a hangover in the morning.
reading_mnemonic: This is a combination of 酔う and 払い, put together with some small っ and a rendaku added in because you're drunk.

examples.en: I’m hungover and I also have a cramp in my leg. Today is the worst.
examples.ja: 二日酔いだし、足もつるし今日は最悪だよ。

meaning_mnemonic: On the <kanji>second day</kanji>, you experience your <kanji>drunk</kanji>enness a different way... in the form of a <vocabulary>hangover</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 二日 and 酔い put together (the reading for that comes from 酔う).

examples.en: How long have you worked at this gas station?
examples.ja: この給油所ではどのくらい働いているんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>fueling</kanji> (給油) <kanji>place</kanji> is a place where you get things fueled. This can either be a <vocabulary>gas station</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>filling station</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Even though she landed a perfect triple axel, her score didn't go up by much.
examples.ja: 彼女は完璧なトリプルアクセルを跳んだのに、スコアはあまり伸びなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hop</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hop</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to jump</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to leap</vocabulary>. Basically anything that gets both feet off the ground via your own foot propulsion.
reading_mnemonic: Know how 飛ぶ means "to fly"? This is a similar idea, though this time you're not flying nearly as much, because you're just hopping or jumping. Anyways, the readings are the same.

examples.en: Which year of Showa were you born in?
examples.ja: 昭和何年生まれですか。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>shining</kanji> <kanji>peace</kanji> time was a time known as the <vocabulary>Showa Era</vocabulary>. This can also refer to the <vocabulary>Showa Emperor</vocabulary> or just <vocabulary>Showa</vocabulary> itself. Everything Showa is here.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I know that fisherman because he is my brother in law.
examples.ja: 私はその漁師を知っていますよ。私の義理の兄ですから。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>fishing</kanji> <kanji>expert</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fisherman</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading is the りょう reading, because you gotta get in your row boat to be a <vocabulary>fisherman</vocabulary>.

examples.en: I had my fishing boat stolen last night.
examples.ja: 昨夜漁船を盗まれました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>fishing</kanji> <kanji>boat</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fishing boat</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This is a small fishing village and most of the people living here are engaged in fishing.
examples.ja: ここは小さな漁村で、ここに住むほとんどの人は漁業に従事しています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>fishing</kanji> <kanji>industry</kanji> is the <vocabulary>fishing industry</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>fishery</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I got so tired of making up for past mistakes.
examples.ja: 過去の過ちを償うことに、疲れちゃったんだよ。

examples.en: Even if you atoned for your sins with your own death, it wouldn't solve the problem.
examples.ja: たとえあなたが死をもって罪を償っても、問題は解決しないでしょう。

examples.en: A lack of love can't be compensated for with cash or gift certificates.
examples.ja: 愛情不足は現金や商品券で償えるものではありません。

meaning_mnemonic:
To make <kanji>reparation</kanji>s is <vocabulary>to compensate for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to make up for</vocabulary> something. You're going <vocabulary>to atone for</vocabulary> your sins.

This word is mainly used when someone is taking responsibility for a mistake, a wrongdoing, or a loss by providing compensation or otherwise making things right.
reading_mnemonic:
This verb uses the kun'yomi reading of the kanji. You haven't learned that yet, so here's mnemonic to help you:

If you want <vocabulary>to compensate for</vocabulary> the wrongs you've done to me, just give me <reading>two</reading> <reading>goo</reading>d <reading>na</reading>chos (つぐな). You can do all kinds of bad stuff to me, I'll be happy and remain your friend as long as you feed me two good nachos <vocabulary>to make up for</vocabulary> it after.

examples.en: I ripped a fisherman’s nets by mistake while taking pictures, so I had to reimburse him.
examples.ja: 撮影中に漁師さんの網を誤って破いてしまったため、弁償しなくてはならなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: My <kanji>dialect</kanji> has offended you? I will make <kanji>reparation</kanji> by giving you a <vocabulary>reimbursement</vocabulary> and some <vocabulary>compensation</vocabulary>. I'm sorry my dialect was so bad you couldn't understand the speech. Here's your money back.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This prison is full at the moment, so we’ll put you on the waiting list.
examples.ja: この刑務所は今満員なので、キャンセル待ちとさせて頂きますね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>punish</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji> <kanji>facility</kanji> is the place you go to do your punishment tasks. It is a <vocabulary>jail</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>prison</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The execution was delayed for five hours.
examples.ja: 死刑執行は五時間も遅れました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>death</kanji> <kanji>punish</kanji>ment is the <vocabulary>death penalty</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Without warning that officer grabbed my girlfriend’s arm and kissed her. So I punched him and he arrested me. It’s unfair.
examples.ja: その刑事は俺の彼女の腕を突然掴んで、彼女にキスをしたんだ。だから、俺はそいつを殴りつけてやったんだけど、そしたら逮捕されたんだよ。そんなの不公平だよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know 事 means "occurrence," but it can also mean "matter." And someone who handles <kanji>punish</kanji>ment <kanji>matter</kanji>s is someone like a <vocabulary>police detective</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>detective</vocabulary>) trying to find and punish the bad guys.

刑事 isn't an official job title but a common way to refer to a police officer whose job is to investigate crimes and arrest criminals. Depending on the context, it can also refer to matters that fall under criminal law, like 刑事事件 (criminal case).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The convict was released after serving a fifteen-year prison term, but he had nowhere to go.
examples.ja: その囚人は、十五年間の刑期を務めた後で釈放されたが、行く当てがなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>punish</kanji> <kanji>period of time</kanji> is the time in which you are being punished in prison. This is your <vocabulary>prison term</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: In order to root out crime, I think we should restore all the brutal punishments, like burning people at the stake.
examples.ja: 犯罪を根絶するには、火あぶりの刑みたいな残酷な刑罰を全部復活させるべきだと思うね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>punish</kanji> <kanji>penalty</kanji> is a <vocabulary>punishment</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This is the first time I've been given a life sentence.
examples.ja: 終身刑を言い渡されたのは初めてです。

meaning_mnemonic: Until their <kanji>end</kanji>, <kanji>somebody</kanji> is being <kanji>punish</kanji>ed. If they're being punished until their end, they've probably been given a <vocabulary>life sentence</vocabulary>, aka <vocabulary>life imprisonment</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My distrust for my wife is only growing stronger.
examples.ja: 妻への不信感は募るばかりです。

examples.en: They seem to be recruiting volunteers right now.
examples.ja: 今、ボランティアを募ってるらしいよ。

examples.en: Let's all appeal for funding together!
examples.ja: みんなで募金を募りましょう。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji is <kanji>recruit</kanji>, so this verb vocab version can also mean <vocabulary>to recruit</vocabulary>. However, its primary meaning is <vocabulary>to appeal for something</vocabulary>, like a job position or donations.

This verb can also be intransitive (oh my!) and mean <vocabulary>to grow stronger</vocabulary>, usually in reference to some sort of feelings or emotions. Make sure to check out the common word combinations for some example usages!
reading_mnemonic: You'd like <vocabulary>to appeal for</vocabulary> <reading>two, no</reading> (つの), three things! Three!

examples.en: Could you break a ten thousand yen bill? If you can I'll donate a thousand yen to your fundraiser.
examples.ja: 一万円札を崩してもらうことはできますか？もしそれができるなら、千円札を募金します。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>recruit</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> you are trying to raise money. In other words, you're <vocabulary>fundraising</vocabulary>.

募金 originally just referred to the act of collecting <vocabulary>donations</vocabulary> for a cause, such as disaster relief, charity, or nonprofit activities. But nowadays, it can also mean the act of donating money for such a cause.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Tofugu is still recruiting bloggers.
examples.ja: トーフグはまだブロガーを募集中ですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
I want to <kanji>recruit</kanji> some people, so let's <kanji>gather</kanji> them up and do some <vocabulary>recruiting</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>solicitation</vocabulary> to get them.

募集 means looking for participants — whether that means job applicants, volunteers, contestants, or new club members. You'll often see it in official announcements and job ads.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You can get the application form at the courthouse.
examples.ja: 応募用紙は裁判所でもらえますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: I <kanji>respond</kanji> to your <kanji>recruit</kanji>ment with this <vocabulary>application</vocabulary> to try and join your group.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We want you to direct this project.
examples.ja: あなたにこのプロジェクトの指揮を執ってもらいたいんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
You learned that 執 means "<kanji>tenacious</kanji>," but it can also mean "carry out." The verb version here means <vocabulary>to take up</vocabulary>, like taking up a task or responsibility, or <vocabulary>to carry out</vocabulary>. 

執る is a formal word that means taking something in hand and carrying out an action. 筆を執る means "to take up the pen," for example, but also implies you're starting to write something meaningful. From this, 執る is also often used when someone takes charge of an important task or adopts a firm stance on something, like 指揮を執る (to take command).
reading_mnemonic: Notice how the word "take" is in this verb. If you take something, you might say 取る. This word shares take's reading.

examples.en: I'd like to write a novel about a guy who has an abnormal obsession with money.
examples.ja: 異常なほどお金に執着する男の小説を書いてみたいんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>tenacious</kanji>ly <kanji>wear</kanji> something. You have some kind of <vocabulary>attachment to</vocabulary> it. You can't let go. It's an <vocabulary>obsession</vocabulary>, after all, and you just can't stop <vocabulary>clinging to</vocabulary> it!

執着 usually refers to an unhealthy or excessive attachment to something. An obsession with money, dwelling on the past, or even persisting in your own narrow-minded beliefs — these are all kinds of 執着.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When was the last time you wrote a short story?
examples.ja: 最後に短編小説を執筆したのはいつですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
You learned that 執 means "tenacious," but it can also mean "<kanji>carry out</kanji>." So what do you carry out with a <kanji>writing brush</kanji>? You carry out <vocabulary>writing</vocabulary>! But not just any writing — this is <vocabulary>professional writing</vocabulary>, so you better get it right!

執筆 is a formal word for the act of writing, especially professional or important work like novels, magazine columns, news articles, or academic papers.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi reading of the kanji, but both readings are slightly altered: しつ gets shorted to しっ, and ひつ gets rendaku'd to ぴつ. If you're having trouble with the rendaku, just imagine fervently <vocabulary>writing</vocabulary> page after page until your <reading>pits</reading> (ぴつ) start to reek. Mmm, smell those musky pits. That's the smell of someone who's just poured their heart and sweat out onto the page!

examples.en: I couldn’t really see if he stepped on the base or not.
examples.ja: 彼が塁を踏んだのかどうか、よく見えなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: It’s been a long time since he made a base hit. He always hits homeruns.
examples.ja: 彼が塁打を打つのは久しぶりだね。いつもはホームランだからな。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>baseball base</kanji> <kanji>hit</kanji> is a <vocabulary>base hit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>single</vocabulary> in baseball terms. A 二塁打 is a double, a 三塁打 is a triple, and a homerun is something you'll learn here on WaniKani at some point if you haven't already.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned the readings for both of these kanji, so you should be able to read this word already!

examples.en: The umpire at first base kept farting during the game.
examples.ja: あの一塁の塁審、試合中に屁をこきまくってたぜ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>baseball base</kanji> <kanji>judge</kanji> is one who judges things on a baseball field. This is a <vocabulary>baseball umpire</vocabulary>, or more simply, an <vocabulary>umpire</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: He got sick and took a day off work.
examples.ja: 彼は体調を崩して、会社を休んだ。

examples.en: I lost my balance on the stairs and almost fell.
examples.ja: 階段でバランスを崩して転びそうになった。

examples.en: Is there a name for that game where you stick a stick into a mound of sand at the beach, then take turns removing sand until the stick falls over?
examples.ja: ビーチとかで砂の山に木をさして、その木が倒れるまで少しずつ山を崩していく遊びって、名前あるのかな？

examples.en: "Do you have change for a dollar?" "Let me see. I have two quarters and five dimes. Is this good?" "Yup, thanks."
examples.ja: 「1ドル札を崩してもらえませんか？」「ええっと…25セント硬貨が2枚と10セント硬貨が5枚あります。これでよろしいですか？」「はい。有難うございます。」

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji is <kanji>crumble</kanji>, and this verb is for when you actively make or let something crumble, so it means <vocabulary>to break down</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to tear down</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to crumble</vocabulary>. It's transitive, so you're the one tearing stuff down. You can remember this because if you go around tearing down people's stuff, they'll probably sue (す).

崩す is for when you break down or loosen something that was solid or properly arranged. You can 崩す a sandcastle at the beach, your posture when you slouch, or even your health when you let yourself get worn down and sick. There are tons of ways to use this tricky word, so be sure check the context section for examples.
reading_mnemonic: You are Zeus, and you have the ability <vocabulary>to break down</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to tear down</vocabulary> everything in your path. The other gods watch you do this and are all like, "That's <reading>coo, Zeu</reading>s (くず). That's so cool, Zeus, that you're able <vocabulary>to crumble</vocabulary> mountains."

examples.en: My poop was so big this morning that the bathroom floor collapsed.
examples.ja: 今朝の俺のクソが大き過ぎて、トイレの床が崩壊したんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: When something begins to <kanji>crumble</kanji> and <kanji>break</kanji>, it will certainly <vocabulary>collapse</vocabulary> at some point. It just can't hold up under the pressure.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My mother might be suffering from dementia.
examples.ja: 母が認知症を患ってるかもしれないんです。

examples.en: People afflicted with PTSD are more likely to reverse daytime and nighttime.
examples.ja: PTSDを患うと、昼夜逆転の生活になりやすい。

examples.en: In the shelter there are many homeless people sick with tuberculosis.
examples.ja: シェルターには、結核を患うホームレスの人がたくさんいます。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>afflicted</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be afflicted with</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to suffer from</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: I was afflicted with an ancient Egyptian disease that turned me into sun god Ra, but now I'm okay. I <reading>was a Ra</reading> (わずら), but now I'm just me again.

examples.en: That patient clung to his dream of being a soccer player even though his left leg was paralyzed.
examples.ja: その患者は、左足が麻痺してもなお、サッカー選手になれるという希望に固執していた。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>afflicted</kanji> <kanji>someone</kanji> is someone who is <vocabulary>a patient</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>medical patient</vocabulary>. They are afflicted with some disease which is why they need medical attention.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji and you should be able to read this on your own. Just remember there's rendaku on the second kanji so it turns to じゃ.

examples.en: The understaffed and overcrowded hospital refused to treat the emergency patient and he died, but it’s not all the hospital’s fault.
examples.ja: 人員不足でごった返しになっていた病院が急患の受け入れを断ったせいで、男性が死亡したそうなんだけど、でもそれって病院だけのせいじゃないよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Someone who is so <kanji>afflicted</kanji> that you have to <kanji>hurry</kanji> and help is an <vocabulary>emergency patient</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I decided to return to my country because my mother got sick.
examples.ja: 母親が病気になったので、私は国に戻ることにしました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>return</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to return</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be returned</vocabulary>. This is when something does this on its own. You aren't doing the returning of something in this case.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I completely failed to see the oncoming motorcycle.
examples.ja: 対向するバイクの存在を完璧に見落としていました。

examples.en: I waved at the oncoming car.
examples.ja: 対向する車に向かって手を振りました。

examples.en: Don't drive on high beams on a well-lit street just because there are no oncoming cars. Think about oncoming pedestrians.
examples.ja: 対向する車がいないからって、明るい道でハイビームで走るなよ。対向する歩行者の身になれよな。

meaning_mnemonic: Being in the <kanji>versus</kanji> <kanji>yonder</kanji> (the opposite side) means you are in one yonder and someone is in the other yonder, and you are coming towards each other. So this means <vocabulary>to be oncoming</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to come towards</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The dog was hostile towards me, so I screamed at him, "You are a bad dog!"
examples.ja: 犬が私に反抗したので、「お前は悪い犬だ！」って叱りつけてやりましたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you're <kanji>anti</kanji> something and you <kanji>confront</kanji> the government about it, in some cases you are going <vocabulary>to rebel</vocabulary> against the government... that is, if you're crazy enough about it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The students were forced to resist to the bitter end against authority.
examples.ja: 学生たちは、権威に対して徹底抗戦を強いられました。

meaning_mnemonic: We are ready to <kanji>confront</kanji> <kanji>war</kanji>, if we have to. We are going to start the <vocabulary>resistance</vocabulary> against your regime, confront you, and even make war.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Why do you defy your boss and try to build up antibodies to the virus? Get a vaccination!
examples.ja: どうしてボスに逆らって、そのウィルスへの抗体を作り出そうとするのですか？予防接種を受ける！

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Confront</kanji> your <kanji>body</kanji>? Sounds like it's something that's against bodies... perhaps, something that's <vocabulary>antibody</vocabulary>?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Why did you resist eating the cake?
examples.ja: どうしてあのケーキを食べるのを抵抗したんだ？

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Resist</kanji> and <kanji>confront</kanji> those who pressure or attack you. This is <vocabulary>to resist</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to withstand</vocabulary>.

抵抗する means resisting an external force, whether physically or emotionally.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I think most foreigners usually don't like natto and I'm one of them.
examples.ja: 大抵の外国人は納豆が苦手かと思いますが、私もその一人です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>resist</kanji> is something he <vocabulary>generally</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>usually</vocabulary> does... at least <vocabulary>in most cases</vocabulary>. He's usually a big resistor, that one.

meanings: First Ten Days Of The Month

examples.en: The Japan Meteorological Agency says the rainy season will start at the beginning of June.
examples.ja: 気象庁は六月上旬に梅雨が始まると言っている。

meaning_mnemonic: What are the <kanji>above</kanji> <kanji>ten days</kanji> of the month? They're the <vocabulary>first ten days of the month</vocabulary>, of course, or even just the <vocabulary>beginning of the month</vocabulary>.

examples.ja: 四月の下旬に日本に戻って、六月上旬にまたアメリカに戻ってくる予定です。

meaning_mnemonic: These are the <kanji>below</kanji> <kanji>ten days</kanji> of the month. In other words, the <vocabulary>last ten days of the month</vocabulary>, or even just the <vocabulary>end of the month</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My due day is around the middle of November.
examples.ja: 予定日は十一月の中旬です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>ten days</kanji> is the <vocabulary>middle ten days of the month</vocabulary>. You could also call this the <vocabulary>middle of the month</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Although strawberries aren’t in season, they are used a lot for Christmas cake.
examples.ja: 苺は旬ではありませんが、クリスマスケーキにたくさん使われます。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.

examples.en: My uncle was killed, put in a concrete drum filled with cement, and sunk in Tokyo Bay.
examples.ja: 伯父は、殺されて、ドラム缶の中でコンクリート詰めにされて東京湾に沈められました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though it contains some extra similar meanings as well, like a <vocabulary>bay</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>inlet</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Same reading as what you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: We’ve traced the source of the infection and it was a flock of ducks in Taiwan.
examples.ja: 感染源を台湾のアヒルの群れだと突き止めました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>machine</kanji> <kanji>gulf</kanji> isn't what you'd expect. In fact, looking at the reading will probably help the most first, since this word represents <vocabulary>Taiwan</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is たい for 台, which is a little different from what you learned, but not the end of the world (especially if you can get the meaning down). The わん is however what you learned, so even if you arrive to だいわん, you'll probably realize that this is たいわん.

examples.en: Her words caused him to explode with anger.
examples.ja: 彼女の一言が彼の怒りを爆発させました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Explode</kanji> <kanji>departure</kanji> is when an explode departures from a certain point, causing an <vocabulary>explosion</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I knew taking apart the bomb could be very dangerous, but I was really interested.
examples.ja: 爆弾を分解することは危険だってことは分かってたんだけど、すごく興味があったんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>explode</kanji> <kanji>bullet</kanji> is when an explode shoots out of something like a bullet, but much bigger, like from a <vocabulary>bomb</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Do you have any good April fool's ideas to make our parents explode with laughter?
examples.ja: 母さんと父さんを爆笑させるような、何かいいエイプリルフールの案はある？

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>explode</kanji> with <kanji>laugh</kanji>s. Wow, what <vocabulary>explosive laughter</vocabulary>.

爆笑 means to <vocabulary>burst out laughing</vocabulary>, often loudly and uncontrollably. While it originally referred to group laughter, it can now also be used by and for individuals. You can even use it like <vocabulary>LOL</vocabulary> or LMAO in English: just stick it at the end of your Japanese messages to show you're really laughing it up.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for 笑 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic. Who has come down with explosive laughter? It's the <reading>sho</reading>gun (しょう)! The shogun just can't stop laughing.

examples.en: I have to commit a suicide bombing by the end of this month.
examples.ja: 今月末までに、自爆テロを実行しなくてはなりません。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>explode</kanji>, it means you're blowing up yourself, and probably taking others with you. This is a <vocabulary>suicide bomb</vocabulary>.

自爆 generally refers to <vocabulary>suicide bombing</vocabulary> in a military or terrorist context. Figuratively, it can also mean ruining one's own situation through careless actions, such as scoring an own goal in soccer.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The chocolate factory crumbled to pieces from the bombing.
examples.ja: そのチョコレート工場は、爆撃を受けて粉々になりました。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>explode</kanji> <kanji>attack</kanji> is when someone attacks with exploding things, like bombs. This is a <vocabulary>bombing</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My poop was shaped like a bullet for a gun the other day.
examples.ja: 先日、銃の弾のようなかたちの便が出た。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

弾 refers to <vocabulary>bullet</vocabulary>s and other projectiles, including artillery <vocabulary>shell</vocabulary>s and BB <vocabulary>pellet</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic:
Bullets used to be round, so maybe that's why this vocab shares a たま reading with other words you've learned for round things, like 玉 and 球. Remember those?

If not, just imagine a <vocabulary>bullet</vocabulary> being grabbed out of the air by <reading>Tama</reading>ra (たま), the local ball girl. She heard there was a たま and mistook it for a ball, and now her hand is kinda messed up. Try not to repeat her mistake.

examples.en: The ball bounced off the ground and fell into the lake.
examples.ja: ボールが地面を弾んで湖に落ちた。

examples.en: I am soothed by this video of a cat bouncing absentmindedly on its owner's large belly.
examples.ja: 飼い主の大きいお腹の上で無じゃ気に弾んでいる猫の動画にいやされています。

examples.en: I never expected such a lively conversation between the two of us.
examples.ja: 彼との会話がこんなに弾むなんて、思ってもみなかったわ。

meaning_mnemonic: Weird that this kanji means <kanji>bullet</kanji> but the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to bounce</vocabulary>. Just imagine someone shooting a bullet. What does it do when it hits the right materials? It's going <vocabulary>to bounce</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: If you want to be able <vocabulary>to bounce</vocabulary> on any kind of surface, you should try inflating your <reading>haz</reading>mat (はず) suit. Hazmat suits are airtight, so they're actually really easy to inflate. You can turn yourself into a giant human beach ball and enjoy bouncing around your local toxic waste dump.

examples.en: I expertly dodged a spray of bullets.
examples.ja: 俺は弾丸の雨をとても上手くかわした。

meaning_mnemonic: Back in the day, a <kanji>bullet</kanji> was a <kanji>circle</kanji> shape. So, this word is <vocabulary>bullet</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The 弾 part is okay, but you never learned the on'yomi reading of 丸, which is がん. When you shoot a bullet, you are using a <reading>gun</reading> (がん). Bang!

examples.en: I’m going to submit my report about blind people’s hearing abilities this afternoon.
examples.ja: 今日の午後に、盲目の人の聴力に関するレポートを提出するつもりです。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>listen</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> is your <vocabulary>hearing ability</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Something might be wrong with the phone because it’s weird that no listeners have called in.
examples.ja: 電話が壊れてるのかも。だって、聴者から電話が一本もないなんて、おかしいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>listen</kanji> <kanji>someone</kanji>, is someone who listens. This is a <vocabulary>listener</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

For this word, most often you'll hear the word リスナー but this is a kanji learning site, so you're going to be learning yourself some kanji, you hear?

examples.en: Do you listen to Western music, Mori-kun?
examples.ja: 森くんって、洋楽聴くの？

examples.en: I was listening to music with headphones, so I didn't notice when someone tried to talk to me.
examples.ja: ヘッドホンで音楽を聴いていたので、話しかけられたのに気づかなかったんです。

examples.en: Listening to that soothing song, I've started to get sleepy.
examples.ja: その癒し系の曲を聴いてると、眠くなってきたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>listen</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to listen to</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hear</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The meaning is really similar to 聞く, right? The reading is the same.

examples.en: Someone bugged the Tofugu office, but we have no idea who or why.
examples.ja: 誰かがトーフグのオフィスに盗聴器を仕掛けたのですが、私達は犯人も理由も分かりません。

meaning_mnemonic:
I <kanji>steal</kanji> by <kanji>listen</kanji>ing to what people say. I do this by <vocabulary>wiretapping</vocabulary> their phone and <vocabulary>bugging</vocabulary> their homes.

盗聴 usually refers to deliberate surveillance using devices like hidden microphones or wiretaps.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Her lips left marks on the wine glass and I traced it with my finger.
examples.ja: 私は、ワイングラスに付いた彼女の唇の跡を指でなぞった。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When something leaves <vocabulary>traces</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mark</vocabulary>s behind, it's because they were there, but now they're gone, and you've come <reading>後</reading> (あと) they left.

examples.en: Unless there is a miracle, a hundred people won’t be able to fart at the same time.
examples.ja: 奇跡でも起こらない限り、百人が同時におならをするのは不可能でしょう。

meaning_mnemonic: Some <kanji>odd</kanji> <kanji>traces</kanji> are left over here. We don't really understand what happened, because it was a <vocabulary>miracle</vocabulary>, but it certainly left some odd traces behind.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Although there was no evidence of crime in the room, the police thought that it was a murder case.
examples.ja: 部屋には犯罪の証跡はなかったが、警察は殺人事件ではないかと考えていた。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Evidence</kanji> <kanji>traces</kanji> are little bits of <vocabulary>evidence</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>proof</vocabulary>, left behind. They're the <vocabulary>traces</vocabulary> that show that something happened.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We found a Fugu-shaped stone statue in the ancient ruins.
examples.ja: 古代の遺跡で、フグの形をした石像を見つけました。

meaning_mnemonic: All you <kanji>leave behind</kanji> are <kanji>traces</kanji> of the past. These are the <vocabulary>ruins</vocabulary> of what happened before. The <vocabulary>historic remains</vocabulary>...
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: He apparently spent a lot of money on his girlfriend.
examples.ja: アイツ、彼女のためにかなりお金を遣ったらしい。

examples.en: It's my life, so if I'm gonna live it, I wanna spend my time doing what I love, you know?
examples.ja: 自分の人生なんですから、どうせなら、自分の好きなことに時間を遣いたいじゃないですか。

examples.en: I'm still not very good at using honorific language, but I tried to speak as politely as possible during the interview.
examples.ja: まだ敬語を遣うのは苦手ですが、面接では出来る限りていねいな言葉遣いを心がけました。

examples.en: Customer service is truly a mentally demanding job.
examples.ja: 接客業は本当に神経を遣う仕事です。

examples.en: I think living with my in-laws would mean I'd have to be really attentive to them every day, and I'd get worn out.
examples.ja: 義理の両親と暮らすのって、毎日気を遣うだろうし、疲れちゃうと思うのよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means <kanji>dispatch</kanji>, but the word 遣う itself simply means <vocabulary>to use</vocabulary> because it's basically just a more formal version of 使う. Still, the kanji adds a subtle nuance: it suggests you're sending out some care or intention when using something, usually things like time, money, language, or feelings.

Note that you can almost always use 使う in everyday situations. 遣う is usually found in formal or literary Japanese, including older writing styles or texts that aim for a polished or dignified tone.
reading_mnemonic: Since this is an alternate version of 使う, it has the same reading too. If you remember that, you can remember this word's reading.

examples.en: These kids are all fighting against their diseases.
examples.ja: この子たちは、みんな病気と闘っているんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fight</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to fight</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to struggle</vocabulary>.

When you use 闘う instead of 戦う, it often means fighting with strong will or emotion — like battling illness, hardship, or standing up for a cause. It can be used for physical battles too, but it usually implies there's struggle and fighting spirit behind it.
reading_mnemonic: Your neighborhood is fighting a struggle against car theft. Sadly, your car was stolen. So, you say: "<reading>ta-ta, ca</reading>r (たたか). Ta-ta."

examples.en: The battle robot was full of fighting spirit.

meaning_mnemonic:
You have <kanji>fight</kanji> in you, and you have the <kanji>intention</kanji> to win. You have <vocabulary>fighting spirit</vocabulary>. Right? Right?! Show me your fighting spirit!

闘志 is a relatively formal word that you'll often see in writing about sports, business, or personal challenges.

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

In historical contexts, 陣 refers to an <vocabulary>army camp</vocabulary> or to the <vocabulary>formation</vocabulary>s soldiers used on the battlefield, often in relation to samurai battles. Sometimes, it can even mean the <vocabulary>battle</vocabulary> itself when you see it in the battle's name.

In modern Japanese, that older sense lives on in sports, where 陣 can mean one team's side of the field. More commonly, though, 陣 is used as a suffix for a <vocabulary>group</vocabulary> of people with a shared affiliation, like 報道陣 (press corps) or 教授陣 (faculty).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

陣 and 陣営 both mean "army camp" when used literally, but in modern Japanese 陣営 is also often used to refer to competing <vocabulary>camp</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>faction</vocabulary>s in politics, business, or sports.

Spread the wisdom of cheese consumption with all mankind!

examples.en: The mother bear embraced her baby and licked it all over its face.

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hug</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to embrace</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hold</vocabulary> (in one's arms, that is). It can also mean <vocabulary>to hug</vocabulary>, especially in the form of 抱きしめる.

Keep in mind that depending on the context, 抱く can be a euphemism for something way more sexual than just hugging. Not always, of course, but pretty often, so just be careful how you use it! 抱きしめる is the better option if you're talking about regular old hugs.
reading_mnemonic:
What are you going <vocabulary>to embrace</vocabulary>? How about your <reading>da</reading>d (だ)? Or if he's not around, maybe an <reading>e</reading>-<reading>da</reading>d (いだ)? You know, like a digital version of a dad.

The two readings for this word have different nuances. だく is more for physical holding and hugging, as in 赤ちゃんを抱く (to hold a baby). But when it's something you hold in your heart, like an emotion or feeling, use the いだく reading: 疑問を抱く (to hold doubts) or 夢を抱く (to have a dream), for example.

meaning_mnemonic:
In Japanese, <kanji>pickle</kanji>d <kanji>thing</kanji>s refer to  <vocabulary>Japanese pickled vegetables</vocabulary>!

漬物 refers to <vocabulary>Japanese pickles</vocabulary> made by soaking vegetables like cucumbers, daikon radish, or eggplant in a solution containing ingredients like salt, rice bran paste, vinegar, and soy sauce. They're left to ferment or marinate, enhancing their flavors. In contrast, western pickles are simply called ピクルス.
reading_mnemonic:
You already learned 漬ける (to pickle something), so just take the る off and shove the け into the kanji. You still read it, but it's hiding. It probably shrank in the pickling process. Stick some things (もの) on there and you know the reading! Not bad! 

By the way, sometimes you'll see this word spelled like 漬け物 too.

examples.ja: 肉とジャガイモに串を刺してくれませんか？

examples.en: Yakitori is chicken spitted on skewers.
examples.ja: 焼き鳥とは、串に刺さった鶏肉のことです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

examples.en: Lately, I've been into grilled kale skewers.
examples.ja: 最近、ケールの串焼きにはまっています。

examples.en: I had dinner at a grilled skewer place Friday night.
examples.ja: 金曜日の夜は、串焼き屋さんで夕飯を食べました。

examples.en: Our parakeet's catchphrase is, "Don't turn me into grilled skewers!"
examples.ja: うちのインコは「串焼きにしないで！」が口癖です。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Skewer</kanji>s you grill (焼く) turn into <vocabulary>grilled skewers</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a combination of the kun'yomi readings you already learned. You should be able to read it already!

examples.en: Eyebrow shape varies from person to person.
examples.ja: 眉の形は人によって違う。

examples.en: I want to get my eyebrow pierced soon.
examples.ja: 早く、眉にピアス開けたいな。

examples.en: Did you know paying attention to how eyebrows move makes it easier to perceive facial expressions?
examples.ja: 眉の動きに注目すると表情を捉えやすいって知ってましたか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. This also includes the place where your <vocabulary>eyebrows</vocabulary> live: your <vocabulary>brow</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're staring lovingly at your own <kanji>eyebrows</kanji> in the mirror when your mom walks in and you gasp, "<reading>Ma! You</reading>... (まゆ)" but you're in so much shock you can't finish the sentence, "Ma, you shaved off your eyebrows?!"

examples.en: The company president said, "Who wrote these documents?" while furrowing his brow.
examples.ja: 社長は眉間にシワを寄せながら「この資料は誰が書いた？」と言った。

examples.en: You know, my pug's most attractive feature is the lines on his brow after all.
examples.ja: 私のパグのチャームポイントはやはり眉間のシワです。

examples.en: Please fill in your brow with black marker.
examples.ja: 眉間を黒いマジックで塗りつぶしてください。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>eyebrows</kanji> <kanji>interval</kanji> is that place between your eyebrows called the <vocabulary>brow</vocabulary>. The technical term for this interval between your brows is the <vocabulary>glabella</vocabulary>, but I bet you never use that word. Unless you're... an eyebrow doctor?
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, but it uses the slightly less common けん reading for 間. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

You stare at the beautiful brow on your <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) doll, completely mesmerized. You wish your brow looked as perfectly groomed as his... le sigh~

examples.en: Big sis, carry me!
examples.ja: 姉ちゃん、抱っこして！

examples.en: My daughter sleeps soundly when I hold her in my arms.
examples.ja: 娘は抱っこをしているとぐっすり寝てくれます。

examples.en: We chose a carrier for our friend's baby.
examples.ja: 友達の赤ちゃんのために、抱っこひもを選びました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that the kanji means <kanji>hug</kanji> and the verb 抱く means "to hug". This noun is similar, but it usually means carrying by hugging, so <vocabulary>holding in one's arms</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>carrying</vocabulary>. This is one that children use a lot!
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.
